Tom says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{3 x}+\mathbf{2} \) are parallel. 

Katie says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}-\mathbf{3} \) are parallel.

Who is correct?
construct_name: Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c

text: construct a triangle using angle-side-angle which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 40^{\degree} \) and \( 50^{\degree} \) either side? - draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long - place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot - place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot - draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots - where these lines cross completes the triangle
question: Which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 40^{\degree} \) and \( 50^{\degree} \) either side?
construct_name: Construct a triangle using Angle-Side-Angle
correct_answer:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the other end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle
wrong_answer:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle

question:
Jo and Paul are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Jo says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) anticlockwise"

Paul says: "a rotation of \( +270^{\degree} \) about \( (-1,1)^{\prime \prime} \)

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two trapeziums drawn on it and a centre of rotation marked on, one space to the right and one space up from the origin. Trapezium P has the coordinates: (-4,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-4,1). Trapezium Q has the coordinates: (-4,-2) (-4,0) (-3,0) and (-1,-2).]()
